snippet.textDisplay:
Looking through the comments it seems that a number of people think this video is in some way bias towards a specific ideology.

If the system were to change to PR then smaller parties from both sides of the aisle would benefit - the Brexit Party, the Lib Dems and the Greens would all pick up a significant number of additional seats.

In fact as we mentioned towards then end of the video parties across the political divide are calling for changes. In fact the Brexit Party's manfiesto contains some of the most radical constitutional changes.

Essentially my point is that highlighting the way the electoral system works isn't bias towards either side. Parties from both sides would benefit. Parties from both sides advocated for it.

You're more than welcome to disagree with PR, but to say that it's only being suggested because Labour lost is untrue. The Brexit Party have more to gain from PR than Labour do and that's why their manifesto is full of constitutional changes.

snippet.textDisplay: I generally agree with going with a proportional representative system.  I also feel that you are unfair in your analysis of the election result regarding regional parties (SNP, DUP, PC, etc.).  It would be fairer in those cases to use the total vote / number of seats available (or seats ran for) in in that particular region (eg: the SNP won 48 out of 59 seats in Scotland with ~1,200,00 votes out of ~2,700,000 votes cast) and using these regional numbers to calculate a PR distribution of seats for that particular region.

snippet.textDisplay:
Well, I'll try not to make this too long. Although there is so much to say about this topic. But I'll try to focus.
I actually quite liked (or envy) the idea of a Constituencies bases parliament, though I started to see some issues in the last 1-2 years. Here in Germany, the Bundestag in first place is made up of members of each party in relative proportion of the votes. Secondly there are indeed some MP's (or MdB's as they are called here) representing a constituency. But there is no real connection between a constituency a its representative. (Most people don't actually know what constituency they are in – it's a bit confusing). Somehow that doesn't seem to be too correct.
As you pointed out – and could be seen in recent years – the British system obviously isn't the best one either. So there should be some mixture. Well, the German one, as pointed out, somehow already is a mixture: We have too votes: first one for the constituency's representative, second one for the party we see most fit to represent our political stance. But the results published and regarded in the news etc. are those of the second vote. An in the Bundestag in the end there are also those "overhang mandates" – a peculiarity of directly mixing both systems.
A probable solution: maybe two parliaments/chambers – one made up by relative representation, one by constituency representatives. But oy vey, we already have two chambers: in Germany it's the Bundestag (see above) and the Bundesrat, the latter being made up of proportional representatives of the Bundesländer (as voted in the Bundesländer elections), which is also not constituency based representation. And the British Chambers are known (also to be especially irrepresentative, regarding the House of Lords).
Also, if we speak about (representational) electoral systems, we need to speak about thresholds, such as the current 5% one with the Bundestag, and the cancelled one with the European Parliament.

snippet.textDisplay: This is an utterly useless exercise. There was an extreme focus on tactical voting from all sides, at least to those that are politically engaged enough to regularly read major outlets. This occurred in a country whose public is well aware of the drawbacks of FPTP. You do not mention this yet continue to give this example, and this is where the accusations of bias come from t is not outside of the realm of possibility to infer that given the public focus on tactical voting and the consistent 10% or so of undecided voters polled days before the election, the votes themselves could be drastically different. I agree with all your points and that PR is better, but this is Bercow-levels of wormtonguery.

snippet.textDisplay: This is an English view of a UK problem. The UK parliament has evolved from the English parliament which was set up to advise the crown and gather revenue for it. It has now evolved into the body that runs the UK even though it is still called her majestie's government and her majestie's opposition. It has two inherent problems. One is the one discussed here. First past the post only works where there are just two contestants in an election and this is what the system was originally set up for, as it's only purpose was to advise the monarch. There is other big problem the UK has at the moment. Is it four different countries or just one?If it's four different countries, then each one should be able to decide it's own future and leave the union if it desires, (Just like the UK decided to leave the EU.) This sounds simple, but it's not. England has 553 seats in the UK parliament the other three countries together have 117 seats ( Wales 40 seats, Scotland 55 seats, N. Ireland 18 seats ) This means  English interests run the UK, especially when they clash with the interests of the other three. In contrast the English population is approx. 55 million the rest put together is approx. 11.5 million. Scotland Wales and Northern Ireland have their own parliments England hasn't. These are the big problems the UK will face in the coming years.

snippet.textDisplay:
Morons, this would create a one size fits all and you would end up with parties focusing on large metropolitan areas and ignoring smaller rural areas effectively removing the voice of those. You have to have someone from your community fighting for your community. Proportional representation doesn't work in California where those living in large cities have all they need whilst those in rural areas live in abject poverty.

The system we use is better, you get someone who represents you and this in turn teaches you as a party to appeal to many not just the few. This is the reason why labour didn't get in and the SNP did so well.

If you're happy to oppress and ignore people outside of your city then please support this but if you feel every community should have a voice then you cannot support this.

snippet.textDisplay:
What if every MP who runs can vote in parliment, and the amount of power they have in parliment is represented by the amount of votes they get.
For instance, in a made up constituency of 100 people they vote like this:
40 - conservative
30 - labour
20 - lib dem
5 - green
5 - brexit
And that all would stand in parliment (maybe above a certain threshold of % votes of the constituency) and any vote they make is representative of the people who elected them. Meaning that if the conservative MP votes for something they place 40 votes, but if the labour and lib dem MP from that constituency vote the other way then they hold a majority 50, which represents a larger majority of the people there.

Obviously this has many, many issues and probably wont work in practice, but it's a nice thought experiment.

snippet.textDisplay:
Maybe you could present several different Proportional Voting Systems from other countries, because although the FPP-system or majority voting system has the advantage, to deliver clear governmental majorities more often, it doesn't accurately represent the will of the people and, as we see again now, in such a ludicrous way at times, that it can plunge a country into chaos.

I believe, should Johnson survive the legislative period of 5 years and go through with Brexit, that Britain will face a very hard time and I assume, that Scotland will atleast be on the road to independance, if not alrdy independant and Northern Ireland will be on the road to reunification, if not alrdy reunified with Ireland.
And Britain will face a very difficult, economical crisis after leaving the EU and loosing all these free trade agreements it participated in via the EU.

I even doubt, that Johnson can reign all these 5 years that a House of Commons-parliament usually lasts, but we'll see.

I'm from Germany, and we got a mix of a Majority Vote System and a Proportional Voting System, however, the latter one has the priority in this mix, so it is mostly the later one.
I like it and I think, if Britains are worried about "damaging" the relation between parliament and constituency, this would be a good solution for Britain too, because we still do have constituencies in Germany and our MP's, that didn't get voted in directly via their constituency traditionally still attain themselves to their home town and thus towards a constituency, basically like a "Shadow MP" if you wanna call it like that.

In Theory we also have two major parties and a number of smaller ones, however, due to political major errors and the two major parties working together for years now, we have a fluid party system as of now, with the Greens overtaking the Social Democrats (the German Equivalent to Labour).

I like it and I think, if Britains are worried about "damaging" the relation between parliament and constituency, this would be a good solution for Britain too, because we still do have constituencies in Germany and our MP's, that didn't get voted in directly via their constituency traditionally still attain themselves to their home town and thus towards a constituency, basically like a "Shadow MP" if you wanna call it like that.

In Theory we also have two major parties and a number of smaller ones, however, due to political major errors and the two major parties working together for years now, we have a fluid party system as of now, with the Greens overtaking the Social Democrats (the German Equivalent to Labour).

Since then commentators and politicians have sifted over the results and admitted much was a backlash to the voters feeling disenfranchiesed for years. snippet.textDisplay:
The election illustrates the advantage of election by plurality in single-member districts, what the British call “first past the post.” It can produce a working majority in a political environment of several political parties. It reduces the chances of needing coalitions in order to govern. The purpose of an election is, after all, to elect a government. That fringe parties tend to be cut out of government is not “unfair,” it is, rather, a great advantage in getting something done.

The principle has been explained by Sydney Bailey in his book: British Parliamentary Democracy. While obsolete in a few details, it is nevertheless still worth reading.

snippet.textDisplay:
I would argue that the real problem that you Brits have when talking about PR is that you never had to endure the negative consequences of it. As every Political Scientist would recognize, every electoral system is necessarily characterized by how it position itself along the spectrum representativity / governability. A pure PR is truly representative but at which cost? Political fragmentation, as you highlight in your exposition, and the difficulty in offering a clear winner of an election. Look at countries that experienced a true PR in the past, for instance Italy between 1948 and 1992 included. Count how many governments we had. That was a parody of democracy.
I believe some "majoritarian" corrections should be included if you want a PR system that delivers also some sort of stability. You can introduce a threshold (3%?, 5%?) below which you do not get to be represented, and / or a "prize" to the party (or coalition of parties?) that gets the (relative) majority of votes, you can have regional allocation of seats (a mechanism that substantially mimics the threshold system but has the virtue of rewarding parties, such as the SNP or DUP, that have a strongly concentrated electorate in certain areas. The point is that you cannot expect to gain representativity without giving away at least some of the capacity of a system to produce a clear winner. The negative consequences of that, I believe, are self evident but I am happy to expand on it in case some people wish.

To sum up, this comment is not to say that the first past the post is the best possible electoral system, not even the "least worst" if you want to paraphrase a Churchill famous quote. The point is the superficiality with which the British public that criticise the first past the post advocates a system that surely has its own problems, which are totally overlooked. Whether this is the result of a personal bias or to simple ignorance, I am not sure.

snippet.textDisplay: So if a foot race has a proportional victory system, would it change how medals are handed out? At day's end, first-past-the-post is meant to provide representation to communities via majority rule. It also makes local MP's more relevant, since, with a proportional system you'd have much larger blocks of voters sharing a pool of candidates, which would ultimately concentrate more influence into party operative hands, at the expense of the voters. I don't love the result of the latest UK election, but given that they had unprecedented turnout, and handily won, it's hard to portray their win as some horrible travesty of democracy.

snippet.textDisplay:
The first past the post system is really designed for a system with two major parties. It turns in odd results in elections where three or more parties receive significant votes. It can also exaggerate margins of victory - the Conservatives are not as popular in England and the SNP not as popular in Scotland as the number of seats they won might suggest.
Even when two parties were dominant in the past, odd results still occurred. For example, in 1951 Labour won more votes than the Tories and received its highest ever vote share - 48.8% - in an election it actually lost. The Tory votes were better distributed with fewer votes wasted in unnecessarily large majorities in the seats they won, resulting in them winning more of them.

snippet.textDisplay:
Localised PR solves most of these issues, as I've been saying for years now.

But what is it?


Its very simple. You combine geographical neighbour constituencies into one voting block, for example 5 seats. These 5 constituencies would still return 5 MPs, but the combined electorate votes PR. So for every 20% (100%/5 seats) of the vote your party wins, you get one of those 5 seats. Any remaining seat(s) with no party or candidate having 20% of more of the vote simply goes to whoever has the most votes left.



This system allows for local representation, independents can still stand and have a realistic chance of election and nothing changes in how people need to vote - they still put one X in one box. No need for a complex multi-voting system. It results in a much fairer result and far, far less "ignored" votes.

The number of combined constituencies could depend on the geographical size - for instance, very large constituencies like those in the Scottish Highlands could remain as they are, or maybe only combine 2 or 3 at most, to maintain the "local" representation and access to MP.

Example of how this would work:

The first 5 seats in SW England (as they are literally the edge of the country and easier to group with less complications):
St Ives - Tory
Camborne & Redruth - Tory
Truro & Falmouth - Tory
St Austell & Newquay - Tory
Cornwall North - Tory


Total Votes cast across all 5 seats:
Tory = 141,310 = 52.6%
Labour = 63,556 = 23.7%
Lib Dem = 53,515 = 19.9%
Green = 5,636 = 2.1%
Other = 4,393 = 1.6%
Total Votes = 268,410

So under this new system, for every 20% you get one seat, so all those above 20% get the first seats:
Tory 2 (40%) seats, leaving (52.6 - 40) 12.6% remaining
Labour 1 seat, leaving (23.7 - 20) 3.7% remaining

So 3 of 5 seats already won. Now no party has 20% left, so next 2 seats go to the highest remaining totals, which are:
Lib Dem (19.9%)
and Tory (12.6%)

So the 5 seats would be:
Tory 3 (60% of seats from 52.5% of vote)
Labour 1 (20% of seats from 23.7% of vote)
Lib Dem 1 (20% of seats from 19.9% of vote)

Tories still get a majority, but now other parties get their deserved representation too. Instead of having (100 - 52.6) 47.4% "ignored" votes, under this system its only (3.7 + 2.1 + 1.6) 7.4% "ignored". This really would incentivise more voters to actually vote, as each vote has a far higher chance of actually counting, even in a very one-party place such as this. Would people change who they voted for under this system? A percentage would for sure, no question. But would they have to change the process of how to vote? No. Yet everyone gets a much fairer result and with local representation. Surely a win win for everyone - apart from the minority who play the system to gain power.......

(Note: these seats were chosen for simplicities sake, choose any 5 seats in any area to see the same effect, including Labour or SNP heartlands)
snippet.textOriginal:
Localised PR solves most of these issues, as I've been saying for years now.

But what is it?


Its very simple. You combine geographical neighbour constituencies into one voting block, for example 5 seats. These 5 constituencies would still return 5 MPs, but the combined electorate votes PR. So for every 20% (100%/5 seats) of the vote your party wins, you get one of those 5 seats. Any remaining seat(s) with no party or candidate having 20% of more of the vote simply goes to whoever has the most votes left. 



This system allows for local representation, independents can still stand and have a realistic chance of election and nothing changes in how people need to vote - they still put one X in one box. No need for a complex multi-voting system. It results in a much fairer result and far, far less "ignored" votes.

Giving radical parties a seat means that they won't be merged in with other parties and can more easily be avoided (by the voters). It's also a good warning system. If a radical party gets more seats than normal, that signals to the rest of the country that things are not going well and need to change.

snippet.textDisplay:
Finland we have 10-20 seats per district in most districts, so we get both proportional representation and geographical representation. Second thing we have is that personal votes for candidate on a lists are tallied and list totals determine the number of seats the lists gets and personal votes of each candidate is used to sort the list to determine who gets the seat. So if you vote for a party you still have about 20 candidates to choose from and often you will find candidate you can agree with and vote for that candidate being one to represent the party in parliament. So instead of being tied to single potential candidate you have actual options even after you have chosen a party which you vote.

And almost every government is coalition government where parties write a common program that states the goals, and it avoids single party having power to make decisions for the country that are so stupid that they cannot get other parties to agree with it in exchange for them agreeing on something that other party wants. Every government program is compromise between atleast 3 parties.

snippet.textDisplay: If the voting system were changed the leading parties would adapt to the new system. It's likely that some of the smaller parties would be totally obliterated. It's like the Monday-morning quarterbacking in the 2016 US Election: Trump didn't bother campaigning much in California because he knew he'd lose the state anyway, so why squander resources better directed to the Rust Belt? If the rules were changed to popular vote, he likely would have won anyway because his campaign would have adapted to that strategy, and he would have had a major get-out-the-vote campaign in Northern California, which is largely Republican-based. Your notion that smaller parties would benefit is based on the voting under the current system; the larger parties would simply adapt if there was a new system, and, if anything, the smaller parties would do worse.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm not sure if the Australian Single Transferable Vote is the same as the Ranked Choice Voting being used in Maine and in several US cities, but it also supports instant runoff counting to select the candidate that gains the majority of votes of the ballots surviving the rounds of counting to reach a majority.  This is performed by designing ballots where the voter ranks their order of preference of the candidates to as many levels as they choose.  For each round of counting the ballots, should no candidate receive a majority of the votes cast, the candidate with the least votes is eliminated and  those ballots selecting that candidate are recounted awarding the vote to the next choice candidate on the ballot.  Any ballots with no next choice marked are "exhausted" and set aside.  The procedure is repeated till a candidate receives a majority of the ballots surviving to that round.  A variation would  be that a winner is not declared till one receives a majority of votes cast with the possibility of a physical runoff election if that condition is not met once all ballots have been exhausted.
snippet.textOriginal: I'm not sure if the Australian Single Transferable Vote is the same as the Ranked Choice Voting being used in Maine and in several US cities, but it also supports instant runoff counting to select the candidate that gains the majority of votes of the ballots surviving the rounds of counting to reach a majority.  This is performed by designing ballots where the voter ranks their order of preference of the candidates to as many levels as they choose.  For each round of counting the ballots, should no candidate receive a majority of the votes cast, the candidate with the least votes is eliminated and  those ballots selecting that candidate are recounted awarding the vote to the next choice candidate on the ballot.  Any ballots with no next choice marked are "exhausted" and set aside.  The procedure is repeated till a candidate receives a majority of the ballots surviving to that round.  A variation would  be that a winner is not declared till one receives a majority of votes cast with the possibility of a physical runoff election if that condition is not met once all ballots have been exhausted.

snippet.textDisplay:
This all does make one major assumption - that the most desirable system is one which reflects the will of the people.
While I don't know the specifics of how/why the system was set up in the UK the way it was, and the governing compromises that led to it being that way it there, I do know a little about how it shook down in the US, historically. In the US, if you were to go back in time and complain to the Framers that the voting system didn't reflect the will of the people, they'd likely say "Yes. That's the point*. The people would probably vote for a tyrant if we let them. That's why we're not making a direct democracy, but a Republic, and even then we have to have all these compromises just so that everyone can agree on *some kind of system." The idea that we 'should want' a system that closely reflects the will of the people is a generally more recent movement than the systems those movements are trying to affect, and thus it is an uphill battle - the system just wasn't originally designed with that in mind to begin with, so it's rough going.

That's not to say that it isn't worth it. There's certainly a lot of room to debate what ought to be desirable in a system and why. There are people who dedicate their entire careers to that question and those that stem from it. But the idea that the most desirable system is one which closely reflects the will of the people is, at the very least, not as much of a self-evident position from which to begin as it is often treated.

snippet.textDisplay: The more you deny that this is a video with a partisan bias, the more obvious to me (as a non-UK viewer) that this is exactly in fact what it is.  I didn't miss your live feed where you were clearly rooting on Labor and the Lib Dems.  Not only that, but the UK had the opportunity with a direct referendum a few years ago to adopt a PR system, and it failed.  The reason it failed is that PR systems in a parliamentary system lead to hung governments (see Belgium).  It seems clear to me that you want a PR system because such a system would have allowed for a "national unity govt" under Corbyn to kill Brexit, and that was NOT what the voters wanted.

snippet.textDisplay: I would suggest you read up some of the comments on the idea behind checks and balances and electoral college in the United States.  It is not necessarily about bias towards a specific party but to urban vs rural areas.  A straight proportional system like you are proposing would heavily incentivize politicians and political parties to focus as much effort as possible at major urban centers since that is where the greatest concentration of votes are.  There has been a lot written about this by people much more informed than myself, I would say that many of the same arguments that apply to electoral college would apply to this as well, and that many people (even since it was first conceived) view it as a vital part of the checks and balances system in the US.

snippet.textDisplay:
And if things were made proportional nothing would get done as the larger number of groups argue over what to do or not.
Proportional voting can easily be argued to defeat the purpose of voting in representatives in the first place (to get a group of people in place to make decisions without the issues of sifting through large groups of opinions).
Of major note is that we got a similar argument for changing how voting works in the USA - by the dems after they lost the running for president. Their argument was similarly shallow and biased, which would set them up for future success at the cost of much of the country (due to populations being primarily in cities, where people know jack about how things work in the rural world).
While not a 1:1 situation, I see the argument for proportional voting in the UK as similar - nothing legit; just a reaction to not being able to lie to the country and get everyone to tow your line.

snippet.textDisplay: I think disincentivizing voting for more extreme parties just encourages stagnation.  It's taking a step in the direction of direct democracy. (This has been known to be a bad thing for 1000+ years).  The current British and American systems are by far the best forms of democracy ever devised.  If you want your left wing parties to be less fragmented, agree on a platform that allows for diversity of thought.  Making forming a majority more difficult as an objective is just condemning the UK for an eternity of the May years where nothing happens ever.
